Legal_Issue: Whether the Board misinterpreted and improperly applied s. 2(3) of the Immigration Act regarding compelling reasons arising from previous persecution
Application_Facts: Jiminez suffered severe persecution in El Salvador; Board dismissed his claim due to changed country conditions without assessing the atrocity of past persecution
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court allowed the application for judicial review
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Court_Ruling: The Board erred by failing to consider the atrocity of Jiminez's persecution under s. 2(3); case remitted for rehearing
Claimant_Status: Asylum seeker claiming Convention refugee status
Defendant_Behavior: Immigration and Refugee Board dismissed claim without proper assessment of s. 2(3)
Grounds_for_Claim: Past persecution in El Salvador, psychological effects, risk upon return
Legal_Standard: Compelling reasons arising out of previous persecution under s. 2(3) of the Immigration Act
Assessment_Factor: Nature and severity of past persecution, psychological impact, changed country conditions
Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly analyze legal provision during refugee status determination
Evidence_Used: Testimony of Jiminez, evidence of persecution in El Salvador, psychological reports
Application_Basis: Claim of continued need for protection due to past persecution despite changed country conditions
Evidence_Assessed: Nature of past persecution, psychological harm, relevance to ongoing risk
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention refugee, protection from removal to El Salvador
Governing_Rule: A person does not cease to be a Convention refugee if there are compelling reasons arising from previous persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to assess whether persecution was sufficiently appalling or atrocious under s. 2(3)
Outcome: Application for judicial review granted; matter remitted for redetermination
Harm_Assessment: Severe persecution experienced in El Salvador, ongoing psychological trauma
Cause_Description: Jiminez claimed refugee status after suffering extreme persecution in El Salvador. His claim was dismissed by the Board.
Evidence_Handling: Psychological effects were considered irrelevant without analyzing the nature of past persecution
Evidence_Issues: Failure to connect psychological evidence with severity of past persecution
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient analysis of the severity and lasting impact of past persecution
Decision_Rationale: The Board must assess the atrocity of past persecution when applying s. 2(3), even if country conditions have changed
Evidentiary_Issues: Board did not properly evaluate compelling reasons arising from past persecution
Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether compelling reasons exist due to previous persecution under s. 2(3)
